facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 434 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 22, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 709 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCiVil Appeal No. 434 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 22, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 709 of 1954.

facts.text: The first respondent Seetharamamma is a Brahmin woman married to Ramakrishnayya who is still alive.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, Seetharamamma, is a Brahmin woman. She was married to one Ramakrishnayya. ... The husband of the first respondent is still alive.

facts.text: Seetharamamma became the concubine of Lingayya, a Sudra, during her husband's lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: During the life-time of her husband she became the concubine of one Lingayya, a Sudra by caste.

facts.text: From 1938 until Lingayya's death in February 1948, Seetharamamma was his permanently kept concubine and lived with him.

anchor.surface_text: From 1938 until the death of Lingayya in February, 1948, she was the permanently kept concubine of Lingayya, and lived with him.

facts.text: Seetharamamma preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya during his lifetime and thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: During this period and thereafter, she preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya.

facts.text: Second, third and fourth respondents are sons of Seetharamamma by Lingayya.

anchor.surface_text: The second, third and fourth respondents are the sons of the first respondent by Lingayya.

facts.text: Appellants are brothers and brother's sons of Lingayya.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the brothers and brothers sons of Lingayya.

facts.text: Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brother's sons.

anchor.surface_text: Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brothers sons.

facts.text: Parties are residents of Choragudi, Bapatla, Andhra Pradesh and governed by Mitakshara school of Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: The parties are residents of Choragudi, Bapatla, number in Andhra Pradesh and governed by the Mitakshara school of Hindu law.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed original suit claiming exclusive entitlement to Lingayya's estate.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, as originally filed, the respondents claimed that they were exclusively entitled to the estate left by Lingayya. The Subordinate Judge and the High Court found...

facts.text: High Court on appeal gave leave to amend plaint for maintenance and remanded suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was originally dismissed by the Subordinate Judge, but on appeal, the High Court gave the respondents leave to amend the plaint by making suitable averments for the award of maintenance, and remanded the suit for trial...

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed maintenance on amended plaint on September 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: At the subsequent trial on the amended plaint, the Subordinate Judge decreed the respondents claim for maintenance and sequential reliefs and awarded to them maintenance during their lifetime out of the estate of Lingayya. The Subordinate Judge passed his decree on September 20, 1954.

facts.text: Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act 1956 came into force during pendency of appeal to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal preferred by the appellants before the High Court, the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act of 1956  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force.

facts.text: High Court held Act provisions apply only to estates of Hindus dying after commencement.

anchor.surface_text: On the first question the High Court held that the relevant provisions of the Act applied only to the estates of Hindus dying after the commencement of the Act...

facts.text: High Court held first respondent was Avaruddha Stree entitled to maintenance though husband alive and connection adulterous.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, the High Court held that the first respondent was an Avaruddha Stree of Lingayya, and was entitled to maintenance from his estate, though her husband was alive and the connection with Lingayya was adulterous.

facts.text: Appellants contend respondents not entitled to maintenance as first respondent not Dasi, sons not Dasiputras.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants, it is contended that the respondents are not entitled to claim any maintenance from the estate of Lingayya under the Hindu law as it stood prior to the commencement of the Act, because  a  the first respondent is not a Dasi...

facts.text: Husband of first respondent still alive and connection with Lingayya was adulterous.

anchor.surface_text: b  the husband of the first husband still alive, and the connection of the first respondent with Lingayya. was adulterous during the period of her intimacy with Lingayya...

facts.text: First respondent Brahmin adulteress, Lingayya Sudra, connection Pratiloma and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: c  the first respondent being a Brahmin adulteress and Lingayya being a Sudra, the connection was Pratiloma and illegal.

facts.text: Suit instituted in December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the respondents were entitled to maintenance during their lives out of the estate of Lingayya under the Hindu law as it stored in 1948, when Lingayya died, in December 1949, when the suit was instituted...

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondents entitled to maintenance under Hindu law as in 1948, not affected by 1956 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore, hold that the claim of the respondents to maintenance for their lives is not affected by the Act.
During the pendency of the appeal preferred by the appellants before the High Court, the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act of 1956  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force.

concepts.interpretation: Provisions not retrospective; do not affect vested rights to maintenance under pre-Act Hindu law from estate of Hindu dying before commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Act is as follows Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act,- a  any text, rule or interpretation of Hindu law or any custom or usage as part of that law in force immediately before the commencement of this Act shall cease to have effect with respect to any matter for which provision is made in this Act

concepts.interpretation: Causes pre-Act Hindu law to cease effect only for matters provided in Act; does not affect vested maintenance rights.

anchor.surface_text: Section 21 defines dependants as meaning certain relatives of the deceased, and under sub-cl  viii , includes his or her minor illegitimate son, so long as he remains a minor. A concubine is not one of the persons within the definition of dependants given in s. 21

issues.text: whether the provisions of the Act are retrospective

anchor.surface_text: The main controversies in the appeal before the High Court were  1  whether the provisions of the Act are retrospective and  2  whether a married woman who left her husband and lived with another as his permanently kept mistress could be regarded as an A varuddha Stree.

issues.text: whether a married woman who left her husband and lived with another as his permanently kept mistress could be regarded as an Avaruddha Stree

anchor.surface_text: and  2  whether a married woman who left her husband and lived with another as his permanently kept mistress could be regarded as an A varuddha Stree. In view of the importance of these questions, the appeal was referred to a Full Bench of the High Court.

It is well recognised that independently of the express texts of the Mitakshara, Ch. I s. 12, V. 3, the illegitimate son of a Sudra was entitled to maintenance out of his fathers estate,

issues.text: whether this right is taken away by the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this right is taken away by the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 19 5 6, which came into force during the pendency of the appeal to the High Court. The Act is intended to amend and codify the law relating to adoptions and maintenance among Hindus.
